title: FTC commissioner says Big Tech firms’ data collection threatens competition
text:
Testifying Friday at the U.S. congressional antitrust subcommittee, Rohit Chopra said fines are insufficient to “fix the core problems that fuel these companies’ data abuses,” citing the Federal Trade Commission’s (FTC) settlements with Facebook for US$5 billion and with Google’s YouTube for US$170 million. He called for regulators pursuing antitrust actions to consider requiring companies to separate lines of business, make their products interoperable and make more intellectual property publicly available. (The Logic)

Talking point: The hearing is part of the antitrust subcommittee’s ongoing look at the technology sector, which comes amid antitrust investigations by the FTC, the U.S. Justice Department, and several states’ attorneys general. Chopra is advocating for regulators to consider companies’ use and collection of data specifically in those probes, which the European competition commissioner is already doing in a case against Amazon. Canadian policymakers have called for a similar focus—in a December 2018 report, the House ethics committee recommended updating the Competition Bureau’s governing legislation so it would take “non-price effects, such as data-driven mergers, into account” when reviewing large deals. In May, Innovation Minister Navdeep Bains asked the agency and his department to review the act in light of the economic impacts of digital transformation.
